issue.title: On the inadequacy of the tailSizeInSeconds() override

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: This issue is about a new feature rather than a bug.

issue.body:
**Problem:**

- `tailSizeInSeconds` exist but the default is not really safe, and it is a trap 
- people don't know that `tailSizeInSeconds` exist and has to be overriden for QA
- in general everyone think their plugin has shorter tail that it actually has (for example, you'd think it's 300ms but it's actually 1800ms)


**Solution:**
- [ ] support infinite tail size with `float.infinity` as return value
- [ ] infinite tail size is the new default, because it's not know what a good value should be instead, and infinity now means "always call processAudio"
- [ ] the QA checklist and override DDoc should include comments about how to set the value for maximum profit (but I do think silence detection should be internal to a plugin...)

comment.body:

- Voxengo TEOTE => declares its tail, unlike the VST2
- SuperMassive => for some reason, is kNoTail (0). I think this is an API misreading.

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- in practice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body: Perhaps this is why Walter think badly about "emulating vectors"

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- i npractice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body:
It all stems for the decision to make it work all the time. It the intrinsics were forcing instruction set usage locally, it would force to enforce instruciton set support externally at application level, thus allowing divergent code path.

At the same time, one wouldn't want to mixin the whole intrinsics definition at the point where we know the instruction set needed, that would be a really big mixin.

issue.title: Smoother behavior

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: This issue is about a new feature rather than a bug.

issue.body:
Some requests regarding the smoothers.

1. the linear smoother does not reach the final value, it just remains up to one `dy` below.
This behavior is not necessarily to be considered a bug, but is a bit counter-intuitive.

2. it's desired to have a setter for `T _current` for allowing to set the current smooth value.
Other frameworks have this. It's to ensure that a smoother can take the direct value right away on start.
(in particular for synth, for example when keying a new voice)

issue.title: Fix semantics of masked load/store
issue.body:
From spec and Intel doc, the masked load/store should trigger no segfault.

With AMD spec, it _could_ trigger a segfault.

Now, in reality, it's complicated:
https://erik.science/2019/06/21/AVX-fun.html
and Intel doesn't follow its own specification.

which means the instructions with masked load/store cannot be relied upon at all for accessing non-padded memory.
It is also a sidechannel attack potential attack!

This conveniently make the masked load/store much easier to implement for arm64.

issue.title: On the inadequacy of the tailSizeInSeconds() override

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: This issue is about a new feature rather than a bug.

issue.body:
**Problem:**

- `tailSizeInSeconds` exist but the default is not really safe, and it is a trap 
- people don't know that `tailSizeInSeconds` exist and has to be overriden for QA
- in general everyone think their plugin has shorter tail that it actually has (for example, you'd think it's 300ms but it's actually 1800ms)


**Solution:**
- [ ] support infinite tail size with `float.infinity` as return value
- [ ] infinite tail size is the new default, because it's not know what a good value should be instead, and infinity now means "always call processAudio"
- [ ] the QA checklist and override DDoc should include comments about how to set the value for maximum profit (but I do think silence detection should be internal to a plugin...)

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- in practice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body: Perhaps this is why Walter think badly about "emulating vectors"

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- i npractice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body:
It all stems for the decision to make it work all the time. It the intrinsics were forcing instruction set usage locally, it would force to enforce instruciton set support externally at application level, thus allowing divergent code path.

At the same time, one wouldn't want to mixin the whole intrinsics definition at the point where we know the instruction set needed, that would be a really big mixin.

issue.title: Smoother behavior

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: This issue is about a new feature rather than a bug.

issue.body:
Some requests regarding the smoothers.

1. the linear smoother does not reach the final value, it just remains up to one `dy` below.
This behavior is not necessarily to be considered a bug, but is a bit counter-intuitive.

2. it's desired to have a setter for `T _current` for allowing to set the current smooth value.
Other frameworks have this. It's to ensure that a smoother can take the direct value right away on start.
(in particular for synth, for example when keying a new voice)

issue.title: Fix semantics of masked load/store
issue.body:
From spec and Intel doc, the masked load/store should trigger no segfault.

With AMD spec, it _could_ trigger a segfault.

Now, in reality, it's complicated:
https://erik.science/2019/06/21/AVX-fun.html
and Intel doesn't follow its own specification.

which means the instructions with masked load/store cannot be relied upon at all for accessing non-padded memory.
It is also a sidechannel attack potential attack!

This conveniently make the masked load/store much easier to implement for arm64.

issue.body:
**Problem:**

- `tailSizeInSeconds` exist but the default is not really safe, and it is a trap 
- people don't know that `tailSizeInSeconds` exist and has to be overriden for QA
- in general everyone think their plugin has shorter tail that it actually has (for example, you'd think it's 300ms but it's actually 1800ms)


**Solution:**
- [ ] support infinite tail size with `float.infinity` as return value
- [ ] infinite tail size is the new default, because it's not know what a good value should be instead, and infinity now means "always call processAudio"
- [ ] the QA checklist and override DDoc should include comments about how to set the value for maximum profit (but I do think silence detection should be internal to a plugin...)

comment.body:
Some VST3 tail information
- Kotelnikov (JUCE) => same as VST2
- Voxengo TEOTE => declares its tail, unlike the VST2
- SuperMassive => for some reason, is kNoTail (0). I think this is an API misreading.

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- in practice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body: Perhaps this is why Walter think badly about "emulating vectors"

issue.title: How would be a way to have divergent code path for say using AVX?
issue.body:
- i npractice, using earlier than SSE3 instrution set will get us bad software reviews on the Internet, for consumer software
- but, using latest instructions can be beneficial at times
- intel-intrinsics detect instruction support once, and doesn't allow divergent code paths. Hence, you cannot branch based upon capabilities...

comment.body:
It all stems for the decision to make it work all the time. It the intrinsics were forcing instruction set usage locally, it would force to enforce instruciton set support externally at application level, thus allowing divergent code path.

At the same time, one wouldn't want to mixin the whole intrinsics definition at the point where we know the instruction set needed, that would be a really big mixin.

issue.title: Smoother behavior

labels.name: Enhancement
labels.description: This issue is about a new feature rather than a bug.

issue.body:
Some requests regarding the smoothers.

1. the linear smoother does not reach the final value, it just remains up to one `dy` below.
This behavior is not necessarily to be considered a bug, but is a bit counter-intuitive.

2. it's desired to have a setter for `T _current` for allowing to set the current smooth value.
Other frameworks have this. It's to ensure that a smoother can take the direct value right away on start.
(in particular for synth, for example when keying a new voice)

issue.title: Fix semantics of masked load/store
issue.body:
From spec and Intel doc, the masked load/store should trigger no segfault.

With AMD spec, it _could_ trigger a segfault.

Now, in reality, it's complicated:
https://erik.science/2019/06/21/AVX-fun.html
and Intel doesn't follow its own specification.

which means the instructions with masked load/store cannot be relied upon at all for accessing non-padded memory.
It is also a sidechannel attack potential attack!

This conveniently make the masked load/store much easier to implement for arm64.
